column1: “Employ your time in improving yourself by other men’s writings so that you shall come easily by what others have labored hard for.”“Well I am certainly wiser than this man. It is only too likely that neither of us has any knowledge to boast of; but he thinks that he knows something which he does not know
column2: whereas I am quite conscious of my ignorance. At any rate it seems that I am wiser than he is to this small extent
column3: that I do not think that I know what I do not know.”“True wisdom comes to each of us when we realize how little we understand about life
column5: and the world around us.” “The beginning of wisdom is a definition of terms. ”“What a lot of things there are a man can do without.”“I cannot teach anybody anything. column7: would not be contented with what he would like to have.”“If a man is proud of his wealth
column8: he should not be praised until it is known how he employs it.”“Where there is reverence there is fear
column9: but there is not reverence everywhere that there is fear

column11: but they are idle also who might be better employed.”“One thing only I know
column12: and that is that I know nothing.” “Our prayers should be for blessings in general
column13: for God knows best what is good for us.”“I only wish that ordinary people had an unlimited capacity for doing harm; then they might have an unlimited power for doing good.”“How many are the things I can do without!”“I was really too honest a man to be a politician and live.”“Ordinary people seem not to realize that those who really apply themselves in the right way to philosophy are directly and of their own accord preparing themselves for dying and death.”“The hottest love has the coldest end.” “See one promontory
column16: one river and see all.”“A system of morality which is based on relative emotional values is a mere illusion

column18: and if you get a bad one you will become a philosopher.”“When desire
column19: having rejected reason and overpowered judgment which leads to right
column20: is set in the direction of the pleasure which beauty can inspire
column21: and when again under the influence of its kindred desires it is moved with violent motion towards the beauty of corporeal forms
column22: it acquires a surname from this very violent motion
column23: and is called love.”“I pray Thee
column25: that I may be beautiful within.”“The way to gain a good reputation is to endeavor to be what you desire to appear. ” “Nature has given us two ears
column27: and but one tongue-to the end that we should hear and see more than we speak.”“In childhood be modest
column30: and in old age prudent.”“The end of life is to be like God
column31: and the soul following God will be like Him.”“We are in fact convinced that if we are ever to have pure knowledge of anything

column38: but a citizen of the world.”“Call no man unhappy until he is married.”“Happiness is unrepentant pleasure.”“The unexamined life is not worth living.” “Wars and revolutions and battles are due simply and solely to the body and its desires. column39: because we are slaves in its service.”“No man undertakes a trade he has not learned
column40: even the meanest; yet everyone thinks himself sufficiently qualified for the hardest of all trades
column41: that of government.”“The only good is knowledge and the only evil is ignorance.”“The nearest way to glory is to strive to be what you wish to be thought to be.”“Be slow to fall into friendship; but when thou art in

First
column45: those who manage well the circumstances they encounter day by day. Next
column46: those who are decent and honorable in their intercourse with all men
column47: bearing easily and good naturedly what is offensive in others and being as agreeable and reasonable to their associates as is humanly possible to be… those who hold their pleasures always under control and are not ultimately overcome by their misfortunes… those who are not spoiled by their successes
column48: who do not desert their true selves but hold their ground steadfastly as wise and sober — minded men.”“False words are not only evil in themselves
column49: but they infect the soul with evil.”“The fewer our wants the more we resemble the Gods.”“Life contains but two tragedies. One is not to get your heart’s desire; the other is to get it.”“A multitude of books distracts the mind.” “Whenever
column51: people are deceived and form opinions wide of the truth
column52: it is clear that the error has slid into their minds through the medium of certain resemblances to that truth.”“If I tell you that I would be disobeying the god and on that account it is impossible for me to keep quiet
column53: you won’t be persuaded by me
column54: taking it that I am ionizing. And if I tell you that it is the greatest good for a human being to have discussions every day about virtue and the other things you hear me talking about
column56: and that the unexamined life is not livable for a human being
column57: you will be even less persuaded.”“The hour of departure has arrived and we go our ways; I to die
column58: and you to live. Which is better? Only God knows.”“To fear death
column60: is only to think ourselves wise
column61: without being wise: for it is to think that we know what we do not know. For anything that men can tell
column62: death may be the greatest good that can happen to them: but they fear it as if they knew quite well that it was the greatest of evils. And what is this but that shameful ignorance of thinking that we know what we do not know?”“Think not those faithful who praise all thy words and actions
column63: but those who kindly reprove thy faults.”“Contentment is natural wealth
column64: luxury is artificial poverty.” “Give me beauty in the inward soul; may the outward and the inward man be at one.”“He is rich who is content with the least; for contentment is the wealth of nature.”“Remember
column65: no human condition is ever permanent. Then you will not be overjoyed in good fortune nor too scornful in misfortune.”“Beauty is a short-lived tyranny.”“The only true wisdom is in knowing you know nothing.”“There is only one good
column68: ignorance.”“Wonder is the beginning of wisdom.” “Be kind
column69: for everyone you meet is fighting a hard battle.”“Every action has its pleasures and its price.”“Remember what is unbecoming to do is also unbecoming to speak of.”“Be as you wish to seem.”“Do not do to others what angers you if done to you by others.”“Beware the barrenness of a busy life.” “Bad men live that they may eat and drink
column70: whereas good men eat and drink that they may live.”“I know that I am intelligent

column79: is to be in reality what we would appear to be; and if we observe

It is a shame for a man to grow old without seeing the beauty and strength of which his body is capable.”“I know nothing except the fact of my ignorance.”“Silence is a profound melody
column82: for those who can hear it above all the noise.” “If you don’t get what you want
column83: you suffer; if you get what you don’t want
column84: you suffer; even when you get exactly what you want
column85: you still suffer because you can’t hold on to it forever. Your mind is your predicament. It wants to be free of change. Free of pain
column86: free of the obligations of life and death. But change is law and no amount of pretending will alter that reality.”“There are two kinds of disease of the soul
column87: vice and ignorance.”“Sometimes you put walls up not to keep people out

column90: weak minds discuss people.”“The secret of happiness
column92: is not found in seeking more

column94: slander becomes the tool of the loser.” “Having the fewest wants
column95: I am nearest to the gods.”“The children now love luxury. They have bad manners

column100: saddle the worst horse; for if you can tame one
